Award.AwardTitle: New Scalable Nanomanufacturing Technology: Large-Area Nanoimprint Master Fabrication without Using EBL by Innovative Multi-Set Nanopatterning

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Two central challenges in nanomanufacturing are to generate complex nanopatterns over large areas without using electron beam lithography or similar approaches that are based on a serial writing method, and to generate them at low cost. Large-area complex nanopatterns have enormous technological importance and many commercial applications impacting a broad range of multi-billion dollar industries. However, currently, the most advanced lithography, which is the workhorse in semiconductor chip industry, is extremely expensive and is limited to a 12 inch diameter area, flat surfaces, and a period of about 30 nanometers. This award supports research that explores new path-changing innovative approaches to provide solutions to the above two challenges. The research will uniquely combine knowledge and technologies from multiple disciplines to create large-area nanopatterning. It will lead to new knowledge and technologies in the fabrication of a broad range of large-area complex nanopatterns, and will provide materials and technologies to enable many fields of study and applications, such as, solar cells, solid state lighting, biotechnology, fuel cells, data storage, optical communication, semiconductor integrated circuits, and displays.

To overcome the challenges in nanomanufacturing, the research will explore a new innovative path-changing approach, termed "multi-set nanopatterning" (MSN). MSN can generate complex nanostructures over a large area without using electron beam lithography or similar serial writing methods. The approach comprises of three innovative nonconventional techniques and their creative superposition or multiple uses. They are (i) Fourier nanoimprint patterning, (ii) edge-guided nanopatterning, and (iii) nanostructure self-perfection. Each individual technique alone can create complex nanostructures that could not be generated before, but, when they are combined, they can generate far more complex nanopatterns over a large area at low cost. The research will explore the science and technology of each method and their combined use. Furthermore, the research will advance new approaches in nanoimprint mold duplication and will use large area nanoplasmonics and roll-to-roll nanoimprint as test-beds for technology development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has successfully accomplished its major goals in (a) exploring and developing innovative large area low-cost nanofabrication methods that uses “multi-set nanopatterning” (MSN) to generate complex nanostructures over large area without using electron beam lithography, and (b) applications of the new nanofabrication methods in electronics, optoelectronics, and biosensing.

The MSN comprises three innovative nonconventional technologies and their creative superposition(s) (i.e., multiple uses). They are (i) Fourier nanoimprint patterning, (ii) edge-guided nanopatterning, and (iii) nanostructure self-perfection. Each individual technology alone already can create new complex nanostructures that could not be generated before, but when these technologies are combined together, they can generate far more complex nanopatterns over a large area.

The highlights of key achievements of the project are:

(1)  We developed complex nanopatterns through Fourier Nanoimprint Patterning (FNP) and used it to create complex nanoimprint mold. FNP uses (a) multiple superposition of nanoimprint of a Fourier patterns (linear grating or dot arrays with different periods or the same periods) and formation of several daughter molds to form a complex nanostructures that are slow and/or expansive to make using other methods. Using FNP, we have fabricated various complex nanostructures, including nanoscale moiré patterns. One of the applications of the above patterns is that these Morie patterns are in fact a lens array, useful for focusing, imaging, and light extractions.

 

(2)  MSN-fabricated technologies for manufacturing large-area and uniform nanoimprint mold for 200nm and 400nm-pitch metallic nanomesh.  Particularly, we have developed both 4” hard Si nanomesh mold and 4” soft h-PDMS molds (Figure 4a) for fabricating uniform nanomesh electrodes onto a 4” wafer-size soft and hard substrate. The molds were fabricated using large area interference lithography, Fourier nanoimprint lithography, and multi-set patterning, developed under this program, without using E-beam lithography. Based on simulation study, two types of nanomesh mold were fabricated. One has the pattern of 200-nm pitch and line width of ~20 nm and the other one has 400-nm pitch and linewidth of 75nm. The hard Si nanomesh molds are designed for fabricating nanomesh electrodes on tough soft layers and hard substrates by thermal nanoimprint and the soft h-PDMS molds are designed for fabricating nanomesh electrodes by transfer nanoprinting on some delicate soft layers that cannot survive the solvent used during thermal nanoimprint.

 

(3)   We have developed the fabrication technologies for making nanomesh metallic electrodes on soft-material substrate (PDMS) by transfer nanoimprinting.  There are many advantages and hence needs to put nano-metallic structures on soft layers such as PDMS; example electronics on skin.  However, the PDMS cannot survive the solvent used in thermal nanoimprint. We have solved this problem using a novel transfer nanoprinting process. It starts from fabrication of a transfer- printing mold that is made from a soft material (h-PDMS) and with nanomesh pattern. Then a thin Au film is deposited on the mold followed by a thin Ti adhesion layer (few nanometers thick). The final nanomesh transfer process is done by the transfer-printing mold on the soft-material substrates. The larger-area master mold was fabricated by a combination of interference lithography and multiple Fourier Nanoimprint patterning (FPN) without EBL. Utilizing multi-set nanopatterning technology (MSN), we developed a large-area and uniform nanoimprint mold for 200nm-pitch and 400nm-pitch metallic nanomesh without using E-beam lithography. We also characterized the fabricated Au nanomesh electrodes on the PDMS layer using the new transfer nanopatterning. Our characterization shows that Au nanomesh electrodes have excellent pattern fidelity, excellent electric conductivity, and excellent optical transparency, far superior to ITO.

 

(4)  Large-scale HDNM-OLED nanofabrication through multi-set nanopatterning (MSN).  We utilized MSN and developed a new OLED structure, named high-index deep-groove dielectric-nanomesh OLED (HDNM-OLED) that has a nanostructure patterned glass substrate embedded in a high-index deep-groove nanomesh and capped with a low-index planarization layer, which significantly enhances the light extraction without electrical degradation. Moreover, the HDNM-OLED substrates we developed were fabricated by nanoimprint lithography (NIL) rather than other complicated and time-consuming methods such as laser interference lithography, electron beam lithography (EBL) and focused ion beam lithography (FIB), and hence easy to apply in real large-area manufacture process with high throughput.

 

(5)  We have contributed to the consorted efforts in the PI’s lab to develop and investigated new nanoplasmonic structures for ultra-high sensitivity sensing.  Particularly, the project contributed to further development of a new nanoplasmonic structure, the M-plate (also termed D2PA (Disk-coupled Dots on Pillar Array).  The M-Plate assay platform, invented in PI’s lab, uses a plasmonic nanostructured surface to drastically amplify the signal of optical label in an assay (either protein or nucleic acid assays). We have successfully implemented Ebola detection assay on the M-Plate, and have achieved, compared with conventional assays, over five orders of magnitude sensitivity improvements (e.g., 220 fg/ml sensitivity, and an enhancement factor of 2X10^5) for Ebola biomarkers.


Last Modified: 03/09/2021
Modified by: Stephen Y Chou
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The project has successfully accomplished its major goals in (a) exploring and developing innovative large area low-cost nanofabrication methods that uses "multi-set nanopatterning" (MSN) to generate complex nanostructures over large area without using electron beam lithography, and (b) applications of the new nanofabrication methods in electronics, optoelectronics, and biosensing. The MSN comprises three innovative nonconventional technologies and their creative superposition(s) (i.e., multiple uses). They are (i) Fourier nanoimprint patterning, (ii) edge-guided nanopatterning, and (iii) nanostructure self-perfection. Each individual technology alone already can create new complex nanostructures that could not be generated before, but when these technologies are combined together, they can generate far more complex nanopatterns over a large area. The highlights of key achievements of the project are: (1) We developed complex nanopatterns through Fourier Nanoimprint Patterning (FNP) and used it to create complex nanoimprint mold. FNP uses (a) multiple superposition of nanoimprint of a Fourier patterns (linear grating or dot arrays with different periods or the same periods) and formation of several daughter molds to form a complex nanostructures that are slow and/or expansive to make using other methods. Using FNP, we have fabricated various complex nanostructures, including nanoscale moiré patterns. One of the applications of the above patterns is that these Morie patterns are in fact a lens array, useful for focusing, imaging, and light extractions. (2) MSN-fabricated technologies for manufacturing large-area and uniform nanoimprint mold for 200nm and 400nm-pitch metallic nanomesh. Particularly, we have developed both 4" hard Si nanomesh mold and 4" soft h-PDMS molds (Figure 4a) for fabricating uniform nanomesh electrodes onto a 4" wafer-size soft and hard substrate. The molds were fabricated using large area interference lithography, Fourier nanoimprint lithography, and multi-set patterning, developed under this program, without using E-beam lithography. Based on simulation study, two types of nanomesh mold were fabricated. One has the pattern of 200-nm pitch and line width of ~20 nm and the other one has 400-nm pitch and linewidth of 75nm. The hard Si nanomesh molds are designed for fabricating nanomesh electrodes on tough soft layers and hard substrates by thermal nanoimprint and the soft h-PDMS molds are designed for fabricating nanomesh electrodes by transfer nanoprinting on some delicate soft layers that cannot survive the solvent used during thermal nanoimprint. (3) We have developed the fabrication technologies for making nanomesh metallic electrodes on soft-material substrate (PDMS) by transfer nanoimprinting. There are many advantages and hence needs to put nano-metallic structures on soft layers such as PDMS; example electronics on skin. However, the PDMS cannot survive the solvent used in thermal nanoimprint. We have solved this problem using a novel transfer nanoprinting process. It starts from fabrication of a transfer- printing mold that is made from a soft material (h-PDMS) and with nanomesh pattern. Then a thin Au film is deposited on the mold followed by a thin Ti adhesion layer (few nanometers thick). The final nanomesh transfer process is done by the transfer-printing mold on the soft-material substrates. The larger-area master mold was fabricated by a combination of interference lithography and multiple Fourier Nanoimprint patterning (FPN) without EBL. Utilizing multi-set nanopatterning technology (MSN), we developed a large-area and uniform nanoimprint mold for 200nm-pitch and 400nm-pitch metallic nanomesh without using E-beam lithography. We also characterized the fabricated Au nanomesh electrodes on the PDMS layer using the new transfer nanopatterning. Our characterization shows that Au nanomesh electrodes have excellent pattern fidelity, excellent electric conductivity, and excellent optical transparency, far superior to ITO. (4) Large-scale HDNM-OLED nanofabrication through multi-set nanopatterning (MSN). We utilized MSN and developed a new OLED structure, named high-index deep-groove dielectric-nanomesh OLED (HDNM-OLED) that has a nanostructure patterned glass substrate embedded in a high-index deep-groove nanomesh and capped with a low-index planarization layer, which significantly enhances the light extraction without electrical degradation. Moreover, the HDNM-OLED substrates we developed were fabricated by nanoimprint lithography (NIL) rather than other complicated and time-consuming methods such as laser interference lithography, electron beam lithography (EBL) and focused ion beam lithography (FIB), and hence easy to apply in real large-area manufacture process with high throughput. (5) We have contributed to the consorted efforts in the PI’s lab to develop and investigated new nanoplasmonic structures for ultra-high sensitivity sensing. Particularly, the project contributed to further development of a new nanoplasmonic structure, the M-plate (also termed D2PA (Disk-coupled Dots on Pillar Array). The M-Plate assay platform, invented in PI’s lab, uses a plasmonic nanostructured surface to drastically amplify the signal of optical label in an assay (either protein or nucleic acid assays). We have successfully implemented Ebola detection assay on the M-Plate, and have achieved, compared with conventional assays, over five orders of magnitude sensitivity improvements (e.g., 220 fg/ml sensitivity, and an enhancement factor of 2X10^5) for Ebola biomarkers.
